xxl.core.collections.bags
Class ContainerBag

java.lang.Object
  xxl.core.collections.bags.AbstractBag
      xxl.core.collections.bags.ContainerBag
All Implemented Interfaces:
Bag
public class ContainerBag
extends AbstractBag

This class provides an implementation of the Bag interface that internally uses a container to store its elements.

Because this bag implementation only wraps a container and redirects every method call to a corresponding method of the underlying container, its performance and cursor behavior depends on the container's functionality and cursor behavior.

Usage example (1). 

     // create a new container bag

     ContainerBag bag = new ContainerBag();

     // create an iteration over 20 random Integers (between 0 and 100)

     Iterator iterator = new DiscreteRandomNumber(new JavaDiscreteRandomWrapper(100), 20);

     // insert all elements of the given iterator

     bag.insertAll(iterator);

     // create a cursor that iterates over the elements of the bag

     Cursor cursor = bag.cursor();

     // print all elements of the cursor (bag)

     while (cursor.hasNext())
         System.out.println(cursor.next());

     // close the open iterator, cursor and bag after use

     ((Cursor)iterator).close();
     cursor.close();
     bag.close();
Usage example (2). 
     // create a new container

     Container container = new MapContainer();

     // create an iteration over the Integer between 0 and 19

     iterator = new Enumerator(20);

     // insert all elements of the iterator into the container

     Cursors.consume(container.insertAll(iterator));

     // create a new container bag that contains all elements of the container

     bag = new ContainerBag(container);

     // create a cursor that iterates over the elements of the bag

     cursor = bag.cursor();

     // remove every even Integer from the cursor (and the underlying container bag)

     while (cursor.hasNext()) {
         int i = ((Integer)cursor.next()).intValue();
         if (i%2 == 0)
             cursor.remove();
     }

     // create a cursor that iterates over the elements of the bag

     cursor = bag.cursor();

     // print all elements of the cursor (bag)

     while (cursor.hasNext())
         System.out.println(cursor.next());

     // close the open iterator, cursor and bag after use

     ((Cursor)iterator).close();
     cursor.close();
     bag.close();

See Also:
Cursor, Cursors, Iterator, Function

Field Detail

FACTORY_METHOD

public static final Function<java.lang.Object,ContainerBag> FACTORY_METHOD
A factory method to create a new ContainerBag (see contract for FACTORY_METHOD in interface Bag). It may be invoked with a parameter list (for further details see Function) of containers, an iterator or without any parameters. A parameter list of containers will be used to initialize the internally used container with the container at index 0 and an iterator will be used to insert the contained elements into the new ContainerBag.

See Also:
Function

container

protected Container container
The container is internally used to store the elements of the bag.

Constructor Detail

ContainerBag

public ContainerBag(Container container)
Constructs a bag containing the elements of the container. The specified container is internally used to store the elements of the bag.

Parameters:
container - the container that is used to initialize the internally used container.

ContainerBag

public ContainerBag()
Constructs an empty bag. This bag instantiates a new MapContainer in order to store its elements. This constructor is equivalent to the call of ContainerBag(new MapContainer()).

ContainerBag

public ContainerBag(Container container,
                    java.util.Iterator iterator)
Constructs a bag containing the elements of the container and the specified iterator. For the most cases the container is used to initialize the internally used container in order to guartantee a desired performance. This constructor calls the constructor with the specified container and uses the insertAll method to insert the elements of the specified iterator.

Parameters:
container - the container that is used to initialize the internally used container.
iterator - the iterator whose elements are to be placed into this bag.

ContainerBag

public ContainerBag(java.util.Iterator iterator)
Constructs a bag containing the elements of the specified iterator. This bag instantiates a new MapContainer in order to store its elements. This constructor is equivalent to the call of ContainerBag(new MapContainer(), iterator).

Parameters:
iterator - the iterator whose elements are to be placed into this bag.
Method Detail

clear

public void clear()
Removes all of the elements from this bag. The bag will be empty after this call so that size() == 0.
This implementation simply calls the clear method of the wrapped container.

Specified by:
clear in interface Bag
Overrides:
clear in class AbstractBag

close

public void close()
Closes this bag and releases any system resources associated with it. This operation is idempotent, i.e., multiple calls of this method take the same effect as a single call. When needed, a closed bag can be implicitly reopened by a consecutive call to one of its methods. Because of having an unspecified behavior when this bag is closed every cursor iterating over the elements of this bag must be closed.
This implementation simply calls the close method of the wrapped container.

Specified by:
close in interface Bag
Overrides:
close in class AbstractBag

cursor

public Cursor cursor()
Returns a cursor to iterate over the elements in this bag without any predefined sequence. The cursor is specifying a view on the elements of this bag so that closing the cursor takes no effect on the bag (e.g., not closing the bag). The behavior of the cursor is unspecified if this bag is modified while the cursor is in progress in any way other than by calling the methods of the cursor.
This implementation simply calls the objects method of the wrapped container.

Specified by:
cursor in interface Bag
Specified by:
cursor in class AbstractBag
Returns:
a cursor to iterate over the elements in this bag without any predefined sequence.

insert

public void insert(java.lang.Object object)
Adds the specified element to this bag. This method does not perform any kind of duplicate detection.
This implementation simply calls the insert method of the wrapped container.

Specified by:
insert in interface Bag
Specified by:
insert in class AbstractBag
Parameters:
object - element to be added to this bag.

insertAll

public void insertAll(java.util.Iterator objects)
Adds all of the elements in the specified iterator to this bag. This method does not perform any kind of duplicate detection. The behavior of this operation is unspecified if the specified iterator is modified while the operation is in progress.
This implementation simply consumes the iterator returned by the wrapped container's insertAll method.

Specified by:
insertAll in interface Bag
Overrides:
insertAll in class AbstractBag
Parameters:
objects - iterator whose elements are to be added to this bag.

size

public int size()
Returns the number of elements in this bag (its cardinality). If this bag contains more than Integer.MAX_VALUE elements, Integer.MAX_VALUE is returned.
This implementation simply calls the size method of the wrapped container.

Specified by:
size in interface Bag
Specified by:
size in class AbstractBag
Returns:
the number of elements in this bag (its cardinality).
